instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message:
Hello,
working on this 17" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> came to me not starting with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> issue (.3V). I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>, but still the same. I also replaced <CHIP>U7750</CHIP>, but still .3V. Does that point to the MCP itself, or is there anything else that could cause this and that I am missing here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message:
I hope you didn't use hot air to replace it.
Did you use same kind of capacitor or bigger one (in size)?
Bigger caps, even removed from scrap boards, have much better ESR than the small new one.

Check all resistors and traces in the area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message:
I used only my Iron for that. <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> I replaced with hot air, but I removed the heat sink from the board and shielded the surrounding area before. Also pointed hot air towards the edge of the board...
I checked everything around <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> before I decided to replace it. Everything seems fine as far as I can tell. So I thought it just could be the chip and replaced it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message: I used <CAPACITOR>C1687</CAPACITOR> from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> for that. l checked again and all resistors and traces around <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> are ok.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message:
Did you try to replace the cap again?
Compare diode mode to ground with good board; in cold state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message: I measured the same voltage with no cap installed at all. I don't have the same board to compare to. My reading is 0.251V to GND on <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>. Maybe somebody has a value/experience to compare it to?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message: Just try another cap...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message: Still the same issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message:
Probably bad resistors, or traces.
Just in acse, replace <CHIP>U7750</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message:
I checked everything in that area. Here is a list of all voltages at <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> Pins. I also replaced <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> with brand new one but still the same.

Pin1 8,4V
Pin2 0V 
Pin3 0V
Pin4 1,5V
Pin5 0V
Pin6 0,87V
Pin7 0V
Pin8 0,32V
Pin9 0,34V
Pin10 0V
Pin11 0,07V
Pin12 0V
Pin13 0,2V
Pin14 0,34V
Pin15 0,34V
Pin16 3,4V

Datasheet says enable (Pin4) should be >2V. <RESISTOR>R7801</RESISTOR> is fine (5K1). I get 3,38V at <RESISTOR>R7801</RESISTOR> Pin 2 and 1,5 at Pin 1. Is that normal? I removed <CAPACITOR>C7801</CAPACITOR> for testing but same thing. Other signals (Pin2, 12, Output, Feedback, etc.) could be messed up if the enable is missing or not high enough I think.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message: Force enable signal with 100 ohm  in place of <RESISTOR>R7801</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message: With <RESISTOR>R7801</RESISTOR> = 100R I get 2,8V at IC EN-pin, but rest stays the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message:
2.8V is good enough for enable signal.
Then you have another problem on <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> area.
Possibly broken/corroded trace, or component.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message: OK, I'll look more into that. But you think that it's not the GPU causing this? Could the two transistors controlled by <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> cause this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message:
How do you relate that with GPU?
Is S5 voltage, which MUST appear before MLB turns on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message: Sorry, I mixed that up with <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. I mean MCP as it receives the voltage from <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> and I don't have a reference to my measured resistance on that line. So MCP could pull that voltage down, maybe? I'd try lifting L7770 and see if <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> can produce its voltage then?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message:
How can a buck converter work without its coil???

Did you check/replace <CAPACITOR>C7770</CAPACITOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message: I don’t have the scematic in front of my eyes right now. Without the coil I thought the voltage would be not as steady as with a coil in place. But I would suspect it being higher than a steady .3V. If the multimeter would not be capable of measuring this I would have used my CRT.  My plan was to lift the one pin off the coil and put it at an angle (on the MCP side) so that I can measure the voltage from <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> after the coil with no load attached to it that could pull it down. I will check <CAPACITOR>C7770</CAPACITOR> tomorrow and report back. As I don’t have the schematic with me right now I can’t tell for sure but I probably did already check and maybe replace it. Before opening the threat I looked at pretty much every component and voltage in that circuit…

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message: Please, use Google first and find (also try to understand) how a buck converter works!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message:
Sorry. I had no schematic on hand and wrote that post from my phone in a hurry. You are totally right. There are important signals after the coil that <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> needs, like FB, so it can't work the way I suggested. I thought from my memory of the schematic that lifting L7770 would be equal to removing F7040 on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>... My bad. I'll look at the schematic first next time.

To answer your question: I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7770</CAPACITOR> and still only 0.32V at <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message:
I can't think to anything more than broken trace, or bad adjacent components.
If no short on output and correct enable signal, you should get correct voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> voltage still .3V with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced.
threads.message: Thank you. Then I don't need to worry to have missed something obvious. I'll replace some more components around <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> and see if anything changes.
